Joel Lehman and I are excited to announce our new publication to
appear in =
the Eleventh International Conference on Articifial Life
(ALIFE XI), called=
 "Exploiting Open-Endedness to Solve Problems
Through the Search for Novelt=
y."

The paper is here:

http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications.html#lehman.a=
life08

Direct link: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_alife08.pdf

Thi=
s paper is about a new kind of search (which works with NEAT) that
abandons=
 the longstanding notion in all of machine learning that the
gradient of se=
arch should be measured with respect to the ultimate
objective.  In other w=
ords, it entirely abandons objectives and
thereby also abandons fitness fun=
ctions as the impetus for search. 
Yet remarkably, we still show that such =
an algorithm can perform
*better* than one that actually tries to achieve t=
he objective!  I
believe this strange result has fascinating implications f=
or machine
learning, artificial life, and even biology.

Lately on this for=
um we have often discussed the nagging problem that
the fitness function of=
ten does not properly recognize or reward the
stepping stones on the way to=
 the solution.  I went as far as
suggesting that the fitness function can b=
ecome an *obstacle* to
success (e.g. when we discussed creativity in Picbre=
eder).

While this discussion was largely philosophical, Joel Lehman and I
=
decided to make it concrete and actually introduce an algorithm that
makes =
an automated evolutionary process in *any* domain behave like
humans in Pic=
breeder, that is, like open-ended evolution.  This
approach is called "nove=
lty search."  The algorithm simply searches
for behavior that is novel with=
 respect to what has come before.

The benefit of this approach is that it =
is immune to deception because
it does not even try to achieve the objectiv=
e.  I know it seems
strange but, counterintuitively, we show that in fact i=
t is far more
effective at solving a difficult problem in a deceptive lands=
cape than
fitness-based search.  

In other words, what we are saying is th=
at to achieve some of the most
ambitious objectives we might have for evolu=
tion, we must abandon
trying to explicitly achieve them.  To quote from the=
 end of our
Discussion section:

"In summary, almost like a riddle, novelty=
 search suggests
a surprising new perspective on achievement: To achieve
yo=
ur highest goals, you must be willing to abandon them."

I believe this les=
son is true in practice and is therefore beyond a
philosophical curiosity. =
 In fact, we are instinctively familiar with
it in life in general when peo=
ple say things like "You are trying too
hard" or when we focus so much on s=
omething so far ahead of us in life
that we forget completely to solve the =
short term problems that stand
in our way.  It is no less true in evolution=
 or search in general.

For NEAT, novelty search should open up new opportu=
nities for
discovery that were previously closed off to us.  

I look forwa=
rd to hearing your thoughts on this work.
